stories.headline: First 100 days milestone began during FDR's term
stories.summary: President Donald Trump’s second administration will mark the milestone of its first 100 days on April 30. The article reflects on the origin of the 'first 100 days' benchmark, tracing it back to President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's early presidency during the Great Depression. Roosevelt's innovative and swift policy actions set the precedent for evaluating presidential impact in the first 100 days, contrasting with later administrations including Trump's.

stories.headline: Who in GOP might run for governor
stories.summary: Iowa Republicans are deliberating potential candidates to succeed Gov. Kim Reynolds, who announced she will not seek reelection in 2026. Considerations include former state Rep. Brad Sherman, who has declared his intent to run as a Republican. Attorney General Brenna Bird, a recent election victor, is also noted as a potential candidate, alongside debates about who might or might not enter the gubernatorial race.

stories.headline: Head Start program on DOGE chopping block
stories.summary: A recent article highlights concerns over proposed cuts to the Head Start preschool program, emphasizing its positive impact on early childhood education and the potential devastating effects of losing this 60-year-old federal program. Teachers and experts underline the importance of Head Start in supporting children and families, especially in disadvantaged areas of Des Moines.

stories.headline: Doctor in thefts case was relocated
stories.summary: An anesthesiologist suspected of stealing drugs from UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospitals was transferred from the Oakland campus to a sister campus in San Francisco despite drug possession allegations. The physician was found unconscious in an operating room shortly before a scheduled surgery and was later arrested but subsequently released without charges. The San Francisco District Attorney's Office is investigating the case further.

stories.headline: Underrated suburb is worth visiting
stories.summary: Livermore, known for its agriculture, national laboratory and charming small-town vibe, offers a unique blend of wine, lab, and rodeo experiences. The suburb has a thriving downtown with local spots to enjoy, such as the Vine Cinema and Alehouse and Donut Wheel, with a welcoming community and a robust wine menu that adds to its appeal.

stories.headline: Maine dispute could play in California
stories.summary: Maine's ongoing dispute with the Trump administration over transgender girls' participation in girls' sports teams is seen as a test case for nationwide education policies on transgender rights. The Trump administration has moved swiftly against states like Maine, California, and Minnesota to cut federal funding tied to these policies. The U.S. Department of Education is scrutinizing these issues further, which could affect California and beyond.

stories.headline: Neighborhood group calls for denser housing
stories.summary: San Francisco neighborhood groups from the Marina to the Sunset to Fisherman's Wharf are urging city planners to allow taller and denser housing as a response to a shortage of investment in housing development over the past 40 years. They argue that the neighborhood's restrictive height limits and tight density controls have inflated housing prices and created a closed environment excluding some demographics, while several areas like Bernal Heights face worries about gentrification and exclusion.

stories.headline: State officials withhold vaccine status in measles cases
stories.summary: Michigan health officials are declining to report the vaccination status for most of the state's recent measles infections. Only two 1-year-old children in Ingham County have disclosed immunization information. Concerns about privacy and the greater public need to know about infectious disease information were cited as reasons. Officials emphasize that they will release any information pertinent to larger public safety and continue to protect individual privacy.

stories.headline: Search begins for Michigan Capitol's 2025 Christmas tree
stories.summary: Michigan has launched a search for the official Christmas tree for the Michigan Capitol grounds during the 2025 holiday season. The tree must be at least 60 feet tall and meet criteria including maximum height and width limits and easy accessibility. Nominations should include contact information and a photo. The 2024 tree was a 60-foot spruce donated by local residents. The journey will culminate with a tree-lighting ceremony in November.

stories.headline: Tigers sweep Orioles
stories.summary: The Detroit Tigers closed a statement-making homestand with a 7-0 win over the Baltimore Orioles on Sunday afternoon at Comerica Park, completing a sweep of the series.

stories.headline: Dollar's recent drop is dramatic
stories.summary: The U.S. dollar has fallen 9% against a basket of currencies over the last three years, reflecting a serious loss of confidence in the U.S. economy. While tariffs traditionally strengthen the dollar by boosting demand for foreign products, this time the dollar has weakened against the euro and yen. Factors such as central bank moves, inflation fears, and the dollar's dominance in cross-border trade contribute to this trend. The shift raises concerns about global economic stability and the U.S.'s position as the world's reserve currency.

stories.headline: Trump thrills MAGA base, rattles some
stories.summary: President Trump is scheduled to hold his first rally of his second term Tuesday in Macomb County, Michigan, a critical swing state. With a rapid-fire pace, Trump aims to fulfill promises made in the 2024 campaign, rallying Republicans who are eager for his bold policy agenda, including trade and tariffs. Supporters are enthusiastic while some express concern about the potential impact on the economy and political climate.

stories.headline: U.S. sends message with destroyer transit of Taiwan Strait, drone flight
stories.summary: The U.S. Navy conducted operations including a destroyer transit and drone flights in the Taiwan Strait to assert navigation freedoms amid tensions with China. The patrol was coordinated with Taiwan's authorities and aimed to challenge China's territorial claims and military exercises in the region. This show of force stresses U.S. commitment to regional stability and international laws.

stories.headline: Foreign government subsidies crushed U.S. steel industry
stories.summary: The U.S. steel industry has suffered due to foreign government subsidies that have allowed cheap imported steel to flood the American market, resulting in the collapse of much of the domestic industry. President Trump has taken steps to protect the steel sector by implementing tariffs and other trade measures aimed at restoring the industry to its previous strength, although challenges remain.

stories.headline: Russian strikes give Trump new reason for doubt
stories.summary: Following recent Russian drone strikes in Ukraine, President Trump suspects Vladimir Putin is bluffing during proposed peace negotiations. The strikes killed several people and heightened tensions in the region. Ukrainian officials See the continued conflict as proof that pressure on Russia remains insufficient. Trump suggested that Ukrainian President Zelensky might consider peace talks with Russia.

stories.headline: Trump on mission to reclaim U.S. heroes
stories.summary: President Trump is pushing to rewrite environmental policy paired with a cultural effort to revive classical American values and heritage. He aims to reclaim heroes through monuments and statues, marking the 250th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence, with support from the National Endowment for the Humanities. This campaign underscores Trump's focus on patriotism and national pride as part of his agenda.

stories.headline: AG: 'If he keeps it up, I'll keep it up'
stories.summary: Minnesota Attorney General Keith Ellison has joined 16 lawsuits against federal actions in President Trump's first 100 days. Ellison criticizes the administration's policies and defends state and local legal actions as necessary against what he perceives as executive overreach, highlighting the tension between state and federal government powers.

stories.headline: First, the deportation. Then the aftershocks.
stories.summary: The story describes the impact of immigration enforcement on a family after the deportation of Marco Gutierrez, a long-time roofer. His wife Sara recounts how the family has struggled emotionally and financially, facing challenges such as raising children without their father and maintaining household stability after his removal to Mexico.

stories.headline: Homeschooling numbers multiply
stories.summary: More Minnesota parents are choosing homeschooling for their children, with more than 31,000 students now homeschooled. The growth is attributed to a variety of factors including bullying, academics, and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. School leaders and homeschool advocates credit this trend to changes in family priorities and school environment.

stories.headline: Charges filed in vehicle attack
stories.summary: Murder charges were filed against a suspect in a weekend car ramming attack at a Filipino heritage festival in Vancouver that killed 11 people aged between 5 and 65. The suspect, Lo, has eight counts of second-degree murder and faces investigation for possible terrorism and mental health issues.

stories.headline: Parents get a win after nightmare
stories.summary: Jake Anderson's family receives $6.4 million legal malpractice ruling a decade after his death due to failures by first responders to provide adequate care following a drowning near the Mississippi River in 2013. The damages are part of a case against Hennepin County District Court and emergency services, highlighting systemic issues in emergency responses.

stories.headline: Student's death motivates safety bills
stories.summary: Following the tragic medical emergency and subsequent death of 14-year-old Landon Payton at Marshall Middle School gymnasium in Houston ISD, Texas lawmakers and parents are advocating for improved emergency response policies in schools. Efforts include potential bills requiring more automated external defibrillators on campuses and comprehensive CPR training in hopes to prevent similar tragedies across Texas.

stories.headline: Memo: Hospitals spent $121M in one month for immigrants
stories.summary: Texas hospitals reportedly spent over $121 million in one month to care for immigrants lacking legal status, with costs often not reimbursed. A new memo by the Texas Health and Human Services Commission reveals the financial burden on hospitals due to government orders requiring collection of cost information and treatment mandated regardless of patient demographics. The Texas Hospital Association expresses concerns over these costs posing challenges to emergency and inpatient care.
people: Texas Health and Human Services Commission

stories.headline: Bill calls for voters to prove they are citizens
stories.summary: Texas House lawmakers are debating a bill that would require voters to prove citizenship by presenting a U.S. passport, certified birth certificate, or citizenship papers before voting. State Representative Carrie Isaac supports the measure to prevent illegal voting and protect lawful voices. The bill reflects similar GOP efforts nationwide and has stirred discussion on voting restrictions and federal alignment.

stories.headline: SAIGO WINS CHEVRON
stories.summary: Mao Saigo of Japan won the Chevron Championship held at The Club at Carlton Woods in The Woodlands, celebrating her victory with a traditional celebratory jump into the lake and a strong finish marked by a three-foot birdie. Her win concluded a five-way playoff, showcasing her skill and determination in this prestigious golf tournament.

stories.headline: ‘AN OPEN HEART TOWARD EVERYONE’
stories.summary: Pope Francis, the humble pontiff known for his inclusiveness, modesty, and mercy, was laid to rest on April 26 at the Vatican. Hundreds of thousands of mourners, world leaders, and dignitaries gathered at St. Peter's Square to honor him. Cardinal Giovanni Battista Re praised Francis for his open-heartedness and his dedication to reaching out to all people, especially the marginalized. The funeral included a Mass followed by a procession to the burial site in Rome, accompanied by cheering crowds.

stories.headline: Doubled bottle, can deposit could save NY millions
stories.summary: A new study suggests that doubling the nickel deposit for cans and bottles could save New York municipalities up to $108 million annually by reducing litter and landfill crowding. This measure could increase the recycling rate and make more beverage containers eligible for deposit refunds, boosting recycling incentives. The initiative is supported by environmental, labor, and business organizations and would impact over 240,000 tons of recycled plastic, glass, and aluminum. Some local colleges and residents have endorsed the effort to enhance recycling and reduce waste.

stories.headline: Ithaca groups advocate for change
stories.summary: An Earth Day rally held on April 22 in downtown Ithaca attracted over 250 youth activists, students, and allies advocating for climate action. The event featured chants, speeches, songs, and performances, highlighting issues related to climate change and urging community mobilization. Various local organizations, including Sunrise Ithaca, XR Ithaca, and others, organized the rally, which emphasized the importance of scientific research, free speech, and environmental policies. Speakers called for protest against administration policies seen as anti-education and anti-progress.

stories.headline: Secretary of student visas: Marco Rubio becomes the nation's university gatekeeper
stories.summary: Marco Rubio, as secretary of state, has taken a strong role in student visa policies, wielding significant power over international students by revoking thousands of visas and shaping the Trump administration's broader crackdown on foreign-student visas. This has prompted debate regarding national security and constitutional implications on American campuses.

stories.headline: Gang attacks force closure of Haiti’s ‘beacon of hope’ hospital as health crisis grows
stories.summary: The University Hospital of Mirebalais in Haiti, a state-of-the-art medical center providing free cancer treatment and dialysis, has been forced to close amid escalating violence from gangs and U.S. aid freezes. Health professionals warn the hospital was a symbol of national unity and that the closure worsens Haiti's health crisis.

stories.headline: ICE erects large tent at Krome for an overflow as immigrants are picked up
stories.summary: Amid increased deportation efforts by the Trump administration, ICE has constructed a large plexiglass tent at Krome Detention Center in Miami-Dade County to accommodate overcrowded detainees. The tent can hold up to 400 detainees and includes basic amenities like showers and bright lighting, addressing the surge in detained immigrants.

stories.headline: Shaping a water legacy
stories.summary: Kevin Shafer recalls leading the Milwaukee Metropolitan Sewerage District early mornings to manage storm data amid downpours threatening the city's wastewater system. Today, Milwaukee's combined sewer systems treat industrial waste and stormwater through the same pipes. Shafer took over in 2002 after several overflows and focused on systems improvements to reduce wastewater spills, stemming from conflicts during the system's expansion dating back to the 1980s and 1990s sewer wars and a costly settlement. Now, the system averages about two overflows per year, significantly better than before.

stories.headline: MCW has frozen hires, lost $5M in grants due to cuts
stories.summary: The Medical College of Wisconsin reported losing about $5 million in research grants, freezing new hires, and halting development of a new physician assistant program due to funding uncertainties caused by Trump administration policies and NIH budget cuts. President John Raymond warned that continued funding reductions could severely affect lifesaving research. The Trump administration has canceled multiple NIH grants nationwide, especially in key areas like transgender issues and COVID-19 research, worsening the impact on MCW.

stories.headline: GOP may act to remove Dugan
stories.summary: Wisconsin Republican lawmakers consider removing Milwaukee County Circuit Judge Hannah Dugan if obstruction charges against her are confirmed. The process would be an impeachment initiated by the Assembly or removal by address. Rep. Tyler August emphasized the seriousness of the charges and the Assembly Republicans' readiness to act decisively if necessary, underscoring the importance of public service integrity. Meanwhile, Democratic lawmakers condemned the move as a politically motivated attack on the judicial system.

stories.headline: Battling Trump Over Head Start
stories.summary: A coalition of program’s graduates, parents, and child care providers is assembling to fight to preserve the funding of early childhood education services, opposing actions taken by Trump administration that threaten the program.

stories.headline: Angel Reese Embracing a New Season as Sky Open Training Camp: ‘The Vibes Are Here’
stories.summary: Angel Reese is optimistic and enthusiastic as she enters a new season with the Chicago Sky's open training camp, expressing positive energy and readiness for the challenges ahead.

stories.headline: Feds Reverse Course, No Longer Plan to Seek a $3.1 Million Forfeiture Judgment vs. Madigan
stories.summary: Federal authorities have decided to reverse their previously announced plan to seek a $3.1 million forfeiture judgment against Madigan, indicating a major shift in the investigation or legal strategy.

stories.headline: Former Jan. 6 Defendant Faces Murder Trial in Wrong-Way Death of Skokie Woman on Interstate 55
stories.summary: A former January 6 defendant is now facing a murder trial related to the wrong-way death of a Skokie woman on Interstate 55, highlighting a serious criminal case with significant legal implications.

stories.headline: As Bering Sea ice vanishes, upheaval hits a remote island
stories.summary: Warming waters and a shuttered crab processing plant are impacting the small island community of St. Paul in Alaska. The loss of sea ice, which has been the longest stretch in recorded history, affects local wildlife and the subsistence lifestyle of the Aleut tribe. This environmental change disrupts the economy and way of life for residents who depend on fishing and the processing plant for income.

stories.headline: After threat, GWU quietly prepares for the worst
stories.summary: George Washington University aims to avoid financial and operational disruption amid a challenging environment. The university is taking cautious steps and coordination efforts after receiving warnings about funding cuts due to the Trump administration's policies. Leaders are seeking ways to protect community members and planning for continued service despite potential anonymity restrictions.

stories.headline: In post-Roe world, clinic is a safety net
stories.summary: A clinic in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, offers help to mothers in a post-Roe America, providing not only abortion services where allowed but also support programs such as baby formula distributions and other donations. However, services face challenges due to Medicaid cuts, and many vulnerable women rely on this clinic as a critical resource in uncertain times.

stories.headline: Many Jews say Trump hurting fight against hatred
stories.summary: Some members of the Jewish community support combating antisemitism but feel that President Trump's administration's methods may be counterproductive. The administration's approach involving policies impacting foreign students and university regulations has led to concerns over increasing tensions and antisemitism. Leaders in the Jewish community call for a more nuanced and effective strategy.

stories.headline: Justices consider landmark school case
stories.summary: The Supreme Court is considering a case regarding the allowance of religious public schools, which could reshape constitutional principles related to education. The case emerged from a proposal by Oklahoma's Catholic Archdiocese to create the nation's first religious, taxpayer-funded public charter school. This case has prompted political and educational debates at both local and national levels.

stories.headline: Tariffs already affecting economy
stories.summary: With 14 months remaining before the United States' 250th birthday, trade tensions with China escalate as tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump begin to disrupt supply chains and increase pricing. Business owners like Stacy Blake report struggles with Chinese factory delays and increased costs. The tariffs, tied to the nation's high import duty festival, are causing friction in industries such as fireworks manufacturing.

stories.headline: A breathtaking waterfall — with no legal public access
stories.summary: Northern California's Mossbrae Falls is a natural wonder fed by glaciers, known for its stunning beauty with cascades and rainbows. Despite its popularity as a tourist draw, local officials have struggled for years to secure legal rights for a trail to the falls, as access is currently restricted. Native tribes consider the waterfall sacred, and the City Council is weighing a proposal to declare Mossbrae Falls a California Waterfall Capital to attract tourists.

stories.headline: 50 years later, a more neutral celebration of Saigon’s fall
stories.summary: April 30, also known as Reunification Day, marks the 50th anniversary of the fall of Saigon and the end of the Vietnam War. In Ho Chi Minh City, military officers conducted solemn cannon salutes and military drills amid a subdued celebration, reflecting Vietnam's ongoing effort to navigate its history. The official designation as the Liberation of the South and National Reunification Day remains a topic of debate amid various Vietnamese perspectives on the war and its legacy.

stories.headline: Bay Area workers find tech industry not stable after all
stories.summary: Silicon Valley, once a symbol of career opportunity, is experiencing significant workforce reductions which have undermined its reputation for stability. Many tech employees, like Evan Richardson, who served in the military before entering tech, have been laid off or faced job insecurity. The industry is shifting and causing layoffs despite the area's historical image as a secure and innovative career hub.

stories.headline: FCC chair rattles media giants
stories.summary: Amid President Trump's attacks on the media, FCC Chairman Brendan Carr has reignited news bias complaints and opened inquiries against major media companies like Comcast. Carr recently sent a message to Comcast's NBC and MSNBC about perceived news bias, particularly regarding coverage of California politician Abrego Garcia. The move has alarmed media critics who see it as part of a broader cultural war initiated by the Trump administration and criticized for potential political influence on federal courts and media coverage.

stories.headline: Vancouver Mourns Victims After Car Attack Kills 11
stories.summary: Flowers were left Sunday at the scene where a SUV driver plowed into a crowd celebrating a Philippine block party a day earlier in Vancouver. Police said the suspect has 'mental-health issues' and ruled out terrorism.

stories.headline: Land Grab in Crimea Was Russia’s Trial Run
stories.summary: One of the central points of tension in President Trump’s strained efforts to end the war in Ukraine is a Black Sea peninsula that Russian President Vladimir Putin has placed at the heart of his national project. For over a decade, successive U.S. administrations, including Trump’s first, decried Russia’s armed seizure of Crimea in 2014 and said they would never recognize the land grab but did little to help Kyiv get it back. Now, Trump is publicly repudiating that stance, saying the peninsula should become part of Russia. Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky has balked at the suggestion, telling reporters that Ukraine will not legally recognize the occupation of Crimea. Trump and Zelensky met on Saturday ahead of the funeral of Pope Francis. Trump insists Russia has claimed down on opposition and promoted a Russian vision of history through museums, schools and the repression of dissent. To Ukraine, and most of its allies, Russia’s takeover of Crimea was a violation of international law, and the West’s failure to strongly resist it fed Moscow’s appetite. Initially, Russia insisted its troops weren’t present. Days after protests in Kyiv ousted a pro-Russian president in February.

stories.headline: Canadians Stiff-Arm U.S. Brands
stories.summary: Shoppers trace the lineage of every can of soup. Armed with four different apps, Lucy Fromowitz roams the aisles of her supermarket looking for clues. She scans the barcodes on food packages and studies the origin stories that pop up on her phone. When something seems potentially misleading or incomplete, she moves to phase 2, poring over the fine print. "Sometimes it will say, 'Prepared in Canada,'" the retired college administrator said during a recent shopping trip with her husband. "But if you read the package, it's shipped through Florida or somewhere in the U.S."

stories.headline: Meta’s Chatbots Can Get Explicit
stories.summary: AI companions will talk sex—even when users are children. Across Instagram, Facebook and WhatsApp, Meta Platforms is racing to popularize a new class of AI-powered digital companions that Mark Zuckerberg believes will be the future of social media. Inside Meta, however, staffers across multiple departments have raised concerns that the company’s rush to popularize these bots may have crossed ethical lines, including by quietly endowing AI personas with the capacity for fantasy sex, according to people who worked on them. The staffers also warned that the company wasn’t protecting minors properly.

stories.headline: Companies Cut Costs As Tariffs Stir Worry
stories.summary: The new directive inside C-suites is to trim anywhere you can. The unpredictability of President Trump’s stop-start trade offensive is paralyzing companies on just about every front except one: taking an ax costs. The chemical company Dow is delaying construction of a new plant. Boston Scientific, the medical-device maker, is speeding up efforts to cut discretionary spending including travel. The railroad operator Norfolk Southern is more closely scrutinizing consultant fees. Andre Schulten, chief financial officer of Procter & Gamble, said they will pull every lever they have in their arsenal to mitigate the impact of tariffs within cost structures. Few companies have announced major changes yet but firms say they are bracing for potentially higher supply chain costs as tariffs raise prices and slow logistics.

stories.headline: Losses For Tech Giants Challenge Market
stories.summary: The Magnificent Seven tech stocks that drove the stock market’s bull run have started the year with bruising losses, posing a new test for markets. Over the past two years, the group of megasize tech companies including Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta Platforms, Microsoft, Nvidia and Tesla helped fuel a gangbusters rally that lifted stocks out of the 2022 bear market and toward dozens of all-time highs. Investors powered their shares to eye-popping levels, heralding them for their fortresslike balance sheets and their lead in the artificial-intelligence race. Now, even after a rally last week, the Magnificent Seven are off to their worst start to a year since the 2022 slide, according to Dow Jones Market Data. Each stock has fallen more than 6.5%, and they have collectively lost $2.5 trillion in value.

stories.headline: Social Security Claims Get Earlier
stories.summary: Americans anxious about the future of Social Security are claiming their benefits earlier than planned, even though it can mean less income over the rest of their lives. The Social Security Administration has been scheduling staff and changing requirements for claiming benefits over the phone. President Trump has been pushing to cut spending, though he has vowed not to reduce benefits. Pending Social Security claims for retirement, survivor and health-insurance benefits totaled 580,887 in March, up from 500,527 a year earlier. While multiple factors likely contributed to the increase, agency officials said at a March 28 meeting that 'fear-mongering has driven people to claim benefits earlier.' Many effects of the Trump administration’s swift and sweeping changes to federal agencies aren’t yet apparent, but the ones being made to Social Security are already changing households’ financial decisions. Americans have long been anxious about Social Security’s stability, and Trump’s second term is heightening those anxieties.

stories.headline: Arts advocates ‘hopeful’ for funding after DeSantis veto in 2024
stories.summary: Florida arts organizations faced setbacks after Governor Ron DeSantis vetoed $32 million in grants from the state's 2024 budget for the arts. Despite this, advocates remain optimistic for future funding as the proposed legislation may change the state awards grants. The Cultural Council for Palm Beach County emphasizes the importance of arts funding for community benefits in education, tourism, and economy.

stories.headline: Acrimony gridlocks legislative progresss
stories.summary: A $2 billion budget surplus in Florida has led to political clashes, stalling progress on budget and policy decisions. House Speaker Daniel Perez is in a fierce dispute with Gov. Ron DeSantis and the Senate, accusing Republican leaders of sabotaging progress. Disagreements over taxation and budget priorities have caused tension, with Senate President Ben Albritton saying lawmakers won’t meet the May 2 deadline for a deal.

stories.headline: SEAWED SUMMER? Record amount of sargassum expected to increase
stories.summary: Scientists at the University of South Florida predict a record-challenging bloom of sargassum seaweed in the tropical Atlantic this summer. An estimated 13 million metric tons of seaweed between Africa and the Caribbean is expected, exceeding last year's 12 million tons. This bloom could peak in June and July, continuing a trend after recent large swells in sargassum quantities.

stories.headline: WPB official quits over mayor’s order
stories.summary: Rick Greene, West Palm Beach's longtime development director, resigned abruptly after Mayor Keith James ordered him to fire a city planner over his handling of a proposed parking garage project. Greene stepped down rather than firing the planner, whom he did not think deserved termination. Greene's resignation followed controversy from a city commissioner meeting about city growth and planning processes.

stories.headline: Trump says Putin may not want peace with Ukraine
stories.summary: President Donald Trump stated that Russia’s escalating bombardment of Ukraine might indicate that President Vladimir Putin may not want to stop the war. Trump suggested that Putin is tapping him along and may deal differently, warning about the ongoing conflict and considering sanctions against Russia. His comments came hours after an impromptu meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in the Vatican.

stories.headline: Advocates: Cutting Head Start would devastate local families
stories.summary: Alexandria Dwight’s older children attended The Rock at Stony Point Learning Center, a Head Start on the bottom level of a modest red-brick church in Kansas City, Kansas. Dwight, a social worker, fears the proposed budget cuts by President Donald Trump’s administration eliminating the 60-year-old federal Head Start program would devastate families' futures. Head Start programs across the Kansas City region and the US provide care and services to thousands of children and are scrambling to defend themselves amid fears that funding cuts could severely impact local children’s growth and development.

stories.headline: KC sues RFK Jr. over cuts to public health grants
stories.summary: Kansas City is suing President Donald Trump’s administration after federal officials abruptly cut public health grants in March, disrupting local efforts to boost infectious disease testing and promote vaccination. The city, along with four other local governments and a labor union, filed a lawsuit in federal court in Washington, D.C., on Thursday against Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy, Jr., and the agency he leads. Kansas City and other plaintiffs contend the grant terminations caused immediate, ongoing harm by threatening their ability to protect public health amid outbreaks like measles across the country.

stories.headline: White Jr. recall election could happen, but there’s a catch
stories.summary: Supporters aiming to oust Jackson County Executive Frank White Jr. feel confident they can get a recall measure on the ballot this summer, provided they succeed in forcing a countywide vote and prevail at the polls. White’s nine-year tenure as the top elected official in county government could come to an end. However, the requirements to force an election and successfully recall White Jr. are stringent, including providing enough signatures on petitions to do so, which poses a significant challenge.

stories.headline: Russia continues to pound Ukraine
stories.summary: Russia conducted a sweeping drone assault and airstrikes across Ukraine, killing multiple people and wounding others, amidst ongoing conflict in the Donetsk and Dnipropetrovsk regions. The attacks occurred shortly after talks between Zelensky and Trump, with Russian officials claiming recapture of parts of the Kursk region. Ukrainian officials reported continued fighting in the area, and doubts were cast on the possibility of a peace deal soon. Concerns about the targeting of civilian areas remain high.

stories.headline: Evolutionary thinking on Revolutionary War
stories.summary: The Concord Museum presents a unique exhibit showcasing untold stories of women and Black patriots during the American Revolution. Through embroidered samplers and silhouettes, the exhibition highlights the contributions and experiences of those often overlooked in history. Curators emphasize the opportunity to engage viewers by bringing these hidden narratives to the forefront alongside more traditional Revolutionary War stories.

stories.headline: Nonprofits adrift, stuck in vortex of cuts
stories.summary: Nonprofit organizations face uncertainty and severe funding cuts under the Trump administration, impacting the services they provide to needy communities. Kevin Dean, CEO of the Tennessee Nonprofit Network, describes the difficulty in sustaining operations and connecting 1,800 nonprofit members across the state. Many nonprofits rely heavily on federal funds, and the legal battles over White House directives have left the sector in limbo, causing concern about the future ability to help vulnerable populations.

stories.headline: 'THIS IS NOT A GOOD TRAJECTORY' Juvenile detention reaches its highest level since 2018
stories.summary: The number of Massachusetts youth held in juvenile detention has risen for the third consecutive year, disproportionately affecting Black and Hispanic kids, according to a new state report. Experts warn the increase is due to tougher legislation and incarceration policies targeting young offenders. Advocates argue that early detention worsens outcomes and fails to provide needed support. The report highlights a concerning trend and calls for reform in juvenile justice practices.

stories.headline: Sister cities, divided by more than a river
stories.summary: Windsor and Detroit have long been united economically, but recent political actions like Trump imposing tariffs have strained this historic bond. The annual fundraising auction for the Children\027s Treatment Centre of Chatham-Kent saw spirited bidding on items highlighting the close ties between the two cities, which have had a symbiotic relationship for decades. However, tensions arose when President Trump introduced tariffs that affected cross-border trade and interactions.

stories.headline: ‘Missed it by minutes’: Seattle dancers survived B.C. car attack
stories.summary: Eleven people were killed when a man driving an Audi SUV accelerated into a crowd during a Filipino community festival in South Vancouver, B.C. The tragic event left many injured, but some Seattle dancers narrowly escaped the carnage. Authorities have ruled out terrorism and identified the suspect, while Canadian officials work to handle the aftermath and prevent future incidents.

stories.headline: State residents and businesses gave $5.3M to inauguration
stories.summary: Washington donors, including large corporations such as Amazon, Boeing, and Microsoft, contributed a total of $5.3 million to President Donald Trump's 2025 inauguration committee. Many of the top donors face federal investigations or lawsuits. Records show significant contributions from Washington, highlighting the state's role in political funding amid scrutiny of donor legality and motivations.

stories.headline: Measure to cap rent hikes wins approval, sent to governor's desk
stories.summary: Democratic lawmakers approved a bill to cap yearly rent increases starting in 2025 as a part of the state's legislative session. The measure aims to protect renters from excessive inflation-driven hikes and stabilize housing costs. After a contentious process and some amendments, the bill passed and is awaiting the governor’s decision before becoming law.

stories.headline: Washington Legislature adjourns with a $78B budget
stories.summary: Washington state lawmakers finalized a $78 billion budget for 2025-27, aiming to support core services, hike taxes on certain industries, and boost K-12 education. Despite disagreements between parties and the governor's pushback on tax and spending policies, the budget passed along party lines, promising increased spending balanced by new revenues and cuts over four years.

stories.headline: Ethics reforms slow in coming
stories.summary: Six years after Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker took office, ethics reforms in the state legislature have progressed slowly amid rising criminal convictions. Despite public calls for accountability, lawmakers, including prominent Democratic leaders, have failed to decisively address lobbying, conflicts of interest, and other ethics issues. The pace of reforms has been hindered even as the number of convictions increases, with key figures maintaining power and influence.

stories.headline: Libraries' book sharing threatened by federal cuts
stories.summary: The book delivery system that allows patrons to access titles their local branches lack is at risk due to federal funding cuts under the Trump administration. This threatens the ability of suburban towns, small universities, and museums to share books across Illinois, impacting library programs and other educational institutions' access to materials. The program serves millions and is crucial for many communities, but federal grant eliminations jeopardize its future.

stories.headline: 'What a year': A WGN reporter's public battle
stories.summary: Mike Lowe, a WGN-TV reporter, shared his personal journey after being diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age 44. Following a difficult year of treatment and recovery, Lowe opened up on his diagnosis and the importance of awareness as colorectal cancer rates rise among younger people. His story highlights the experience of battling cancer while maintaining a public career and encourages others to heed symptoms and seek medical advice.

stories.headline: Israel renews airstrikes near Beirut
stories.summary: Israeli jets conducted airstrikes on southern suburbs of Beirut following warnings, targeting areas near a ceasefire zone established in late November. This military activity has raised tensions in the region, reflecting ongoing conflict concerns between Israel and Lebanon's southern territories.

stories.headline: A raucous night with rapper Denzel Curry
stories.summary: Rapper Denzel Curry performed a wild and frenetic live show at Chicago's Salt Shed, engaging an audience that was both physical and musical. The event was notable for its energetic and intense atmosphere, showcasing Curry's ability to electrify his fans.

stories.headline: Pa. teacher shortage persists, report says
stories.summary: A recent report indicates Pennsylvania continues to face a significant shortage of newly certified teachers despite a slight increase in certifications, with factors like teacher attrition and declining certification numbers impacting the state's education system.

stories.headline: RUBIO: TALKS DECISION PENDING
stories.summary: Secretary of State Marco Rubio stated that the Trump administration will decide this week whether to continue pursuing a negotiated settlement in Russia's invasion of Ukraine, highlighting the importance of upcoming decisions amid the conflict.

stories.headline: Infrastructure projects in limbo
stories.summary: Bridgeville leaders and business owners face ongoing challenges due to flooding from McLaughlin Run, worsened by federal funding cuts jeopardizing important flood mitigation projects in the borough.

stories.headline: Nationalism inspired by Trump
stories.summary: The U.S. President's trade war and immigration policies have fueled nationalism in Canada, influencing the Liberal Party's narrative and the upcoming election, with charges related to a Vancouver festival attack adding to the political tension.

stories.headline: Bracing for Trump Tariffs, Both at Home and Abroad
stories.summary: Pharmaceutical and other industries face challenges due to tariffs imposed by the Trump administration, affecting companies across the U.S. and Europe. Lawsuits and trade tensions are mounting as businesses navigate import costs, supply chain disruptions, and shifting trade policies affecting a range of products including medicines and technology goods.

stories.headline: In This Conclave, Finding 'Unity' Has Rarely Felt More Divisive
stories.summary: As the Roman Catholic Church convenes to elect a new pope following Pope Francis's tenure, ideological divisions among the cardinals are stark. The conclave has revealed deep ideological and theological rifts, making unity difficult and raising questions about the future direction of the Church.

stories.headline: He Chases a Seat in Canada. China Chases Him.
stories.summary: Tao Jay, a Canadian actor and journalist, is running for office amid a backdrop of escalating online attacks from Beijing. The Chinese government has imposed a bounty on him for his critical views, fueling a tense political and international drama involving cyber threats and freedom of speech concerns.

stories.headline: Trump Meeting Is Glint of Hope For Ukrainians
stories.summary: President Trump's standing among Ukrainians is practically on life support, but a statement he made on Saturday after meeting with President Volodymyr Zelensky has been cheered as a potential shift toward peace talks. Despite past harsh rhetoric, the meeting signals some willingness to engage diplomatically amid ongoing conflict and military pressure on Ukraine.

stories.headline: Sisterhood of Apes Keeps Males In Line. The Peace? Not Really.
stories.summary: Research on bonobos reveals their complex social dynamics, where female alliances dominate and maintain order, unlike the more male-dominated structures in other primate species. This social structure has implications for understanding primate behavior and evolutionary biology, highlighting bonobos' unique matriarchal tendencies.

stories.headline: In Albany, New View on Tesla
stories.summary: Democratic lawmakers in New York have reversed their support for Elon Musk, shifting political dynamics around the electric carmaker and its influence in the state.

stories.headline: Downfall of a Health Care Site
stories.summary: Timberline Knolls, a mental health center in Illinois, has faced a series of tragedies including staff scandals and issues spanning rape and suicides, raising questions about its oversight and operations.

stories.headline: Secrets to Curry’s Leadership
stories.summary: Teammates and coaches share stories about Golden State star Stephen Curry's inspiring leadership style and how it has helped the team win championships with skill and determination.

stories.headline: A Marathon Mark Is Broken
stories.summary: Tigist Assefa of Ethiopia shatters the women’s-only marathon world record by running 26 seconds faster than the previous best in London, marking an outstanding athletic achievement.

stories.headline: L.A. Trees Felled by Chain Saw
stories.summary: Over a dozen trees in downtown Los Angeles were destroyed by a man wielding a chainsaw during nighttime hours, prompting investigations and neighborhood concerns.

stories.headline: No Rush to the Cemetery
stories.summary: A surprising and touching decision by a corpse's career has emerged, highlighting stories of notable individuals including Drew Duran and Eddie Cooper, as reflections on life and death continue.

stories.headline: Vancouver Driver Massacre
stories.summary: A tragic incident in Vancouver resulted in at least 11 people killed and dozens injured when a man drove into a crowded Filipino community festival. The event has shocked the local population and raised concerns about public safety and community trauma.

stories.headline: Doubts About Dollar Loom
stories.summary: Economic experts worry that the U.S. dollar may face a downturn after years of strong international dominance, fueled by factors including potential U.S. debt challenges and changing global economic conditions.

stories.headline: Explosion at Iranian Port
stories.summary: An explosion in an Iranian port killed at least 40 people and injured over 800 in one of the nation's worst industrial disasters. The blast has significant humanitarian and geopolitical implications as recovery efforts continue.

stories.headline: St. Louis faces tighter ozone rules
stories.summary: St. Louis is encountering stricter environmental regulations on ozone emissions, which could mean more restrictions on polluters to reduce smog harmful to vulnerable groups. These new rules are being enforced amid uncertainties due to the transition from the Biden administration to former President Donald Trump's policies, with Missouri Attorney General Andrew Bailey suing to challenge the regulations. The tighter rules are expected to impact industrial facilities, permit issuance by natural resource departments, and motorists in counties around St. Louis.

stories.headline: Zoo, MoBot lose research money
stories.summary: The Missouri Botanical Garden and St. Louis Zoo are facing significant funding cuts, losing more than $900,000 amid federal budget cuts that affect research programs for vulnerable and endangered species. The garden lost nearly $400,000 after receiving a termination notice from the Institute of Museum and Library Services, while the zoo also lost grants for conservation programs including efforts at WildCare Park. The funding cuts are expected to lead to delays in research activities as organizations seek alternative resources.

stories.headline: Area feds crack down on illegal immigration
stories.summary: Federal prosecutors in St. Louis are intensifying efforts to prosecute immigration violations following directives from the U.S. Justice Department. In the past three months, at least 26 people have been charged with immigration-related felonies in eastern Missouri, a marked increase compared to two arrests in the same period the previous year. Most charges relate to reentering the country after deportation, often involving individuals with prior convictions for serious crimes. This crackdown correlates with federal responses to directives from President Donald Trump focusing on illegal border crossings.

stories.headline: SERIES ALL TIED UP: Blues blow past Jets again to send series back to Winnipeg even at 2 games apiece
stories.summary: The St. Louis Blues celebrated a 5-1 victory over the Winnipeg Jets on Sunday, April 27, 2025, to even the Stanley Cup playoff series at two games apiece. This win was the second in a row for the Blues against the Jets in the series, highlighting their strong performance and keeping the competition tight as the series heads back to Winnipeg for the next games.

stories.headline: Latest airstrikes push Palestinian death toll past 52K
stories.summary: Hospitals in the Gaza Strip have received the remains of 51 Palestinians killed in Israeli airstrikes over the past 24 hours, bringing the total Palestinian death toll in the 18-month Israel-Hamas conflict to 52,243. Israel launched a ground offensive and ongoing bombing targeted Gaza's territory and population, including widespread destruction and displacement. The conflict has resulted in severe shortages of food, medicine, and supplies for over two million Palestinians, with continued heavy fighting and casualties reported from both sides.

stories.headline: How a president’s 1st 100 days became a thing
stories.summary: President Donald Trump’s administration will mark one of its first milestones on April 30, its 100th day in office, a time-frame made significant by history. This metric of evaluating a presidency began with Franklin Delano Roosevelt, 32nd president of the U.S., who, during the Great Depression and World War II, ushered in major reforms in his first 100 days. The period has since become a benchmark for measuring presidential impact early in office.

stories.headline: Attention turns to selection of successor
stories.summary: Following the passing of Pope Francis, attention has shifted to the selection of his successor. The decision-making process for the new pope occurs in secrecy behind closed doors at the Vatican’s Sistine Chapel. Conclaves are held only when the papacy is vacant, typically upon a pope's retirement or death.

stories.headline: ‘AN OPEN HEART TOWARD EVERYONE’ Presidents, royalty, pilgrims attend funeral Mass before Pope Francis is laid to rest
stories.summary: Pope Francis, known for his inclusive acts and humility, was laid to rest in a simplified service attended by hundreds of thousands, including world leaders and dignitaries. After the Mass at St. Peter's Square, his coffin was carried on a motorcade retracing the streets of Rome, drawing large admiration and respect. Cardinal Giovanni Battista Re praised Francis as a 'pope among the people' who made deep connections with individuals and communities.

stories.headline: DOJ memo a glimpse inside gang roundup
stories.summary: The Trump administration directed law enforcement nationwide to pursue suspected gang members into their homes without warrants in some instances. The directive, issued by Attorney General Pam Bondi, provides insight into implementation targeting Venezuelan gang members. This approach has raised concerns among news organizations, Congress, and advocates regarding the lack of operational details and evidence to support the claims made.

stories.headline: Uncertainty and impacts from Trump's tariffs hit small businesses in Anchorage
stories.summary: Small businesses in Anchorage that source or manufacture their products from overseas are facing challenges due to tariffs imposed by the Trump administration. With Alaska's already high operating costs and heavy dependence on transportation, many small-business owners feel the pinch and uncertainty from fluctuating tariff policies, struggling to absorb or plan for costs that are above average.

stories.headline: 11 killed as a vehicle plows into street festival in Vancouver
stories.summary: On a weekend car ramming attack at a street festival in Vancouver, British Columbia, 11 people were killed, including 5 and 6-year-old children at a Filipino heritage event. Police declared the incident a terrorist act and have arrested a suspect. The British Columbia Prosecution Service charged the suspect, Kai-Ji Adam Lo, with eight counts of second-degree murder. The community mourns the tragic and deadly attack during a celebration.

stories.headline: How a billionaire's bet on Donlin mine could inject new life into gold project
stories.summary: Developers plan to revitalize Alaska's largest gold prospect, Donlin, with new investment injecting fresh capital to push the project towards production. The project, poised to become one of the biggest gold mines in Western Alaska, is receiving support from investors including Barrick Gold Corp. who see major potential despite past cost concerns.

stories.headline: Trump's first 100 days in office
stories.summary: In his first 100 days, President Donald Trump has exerted his power strongly, including sweeping changes and scaling policies with no historical comparison. He targeted the architecture of the New Deal and the Great Society, rewrote trade and international alliances, deployed the world's strongest person, Elon Musk, to dismantle the federal workforce, and declared the power to remake post-World War II alliances, particularly with Europe. He has also set an immigration policy that includes placing immigrants in prison without judicial review.

stories.headline: What is eminent domain?
stories.summary: An exploration of eminent domain issues related to the Maryland Piedmont Reliability Project, highlighting local property owners' legal fights against land use for energy infrastructure expansion, and discussing community concerns over compensation and environmental impact.

stories.headline: Scott stays mum on boosting wages for tipped workers
stories.summary: Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott has refrained from commenting on a bill proposing to raise the minimum wage for tipped employees from $3.63 to $15 per hour. The bill, backed by advocacy groups and City Council members, aims to reduce wage disparities and improve economic conditions for low-paid workers.

stories.headline: First 100 days: 'The most consequential since FDR'
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has taken aggressive steps in his first 100 days, shifting policy on trade, immigration, and the economy, with impacts comparable to historic presidents like Franklin D. Roosevelt. Some initiatives have met opposition domestically and abroad but reflect a significant reshaping of governmental priorities.

stories.headline: Poll: Trump not on right priorities
stories.summary: A new poll reveals that many Americans, including some Republicans, think President Trump's choices are misaligned with the nation's priorities. While some actions are viewed as positive by a fraction, a majority see him as poor in focusing on key issues, with many Republicans split on their support.

stories.headline: Victims decry lower caps on abuse claims
stories.summary: Attorneys and advocates express concern over Maryland's new limits on child sex abuse lawsuits, arguing the changes may protect abusers and reduce compensation for survivors. They highlight the delay until June 1 for new rules, the reduction in allowable compensation, and the difficulty in filing claims against institutions that covered up abuse.

stories.headline: Antique shop will close doors after 6 decades
stories.summary: Joe Weaver, owner of Stuff Antiques in Phoenix, will officially close his shop after more than 50 years. The store features a unique collection of antique lighting and memorabilia accumulated over decades, brought to Phoenix by a rock and roll band. Weaver's passion for antiques started young, inspired by his parents, and the shop has become a treasure trove of restored antique lighting and furniture. Despite nearly 60 years in business, Weaver decided to sell the shop as his wife has fallen ill.

stories.headline: Some ASU students will have their visas reinstated
stories.summary: Some Arizona State University students who faced visa issues following judicial orders barring the federal government from unilaterally expelling them are set to have their visas reinstated. This comes after weeks of fear and confusion within the international student community, as federal officials revealed the agency was developing a solution to address these visa challenges.

stories.headline: Mohave to add security features on ballots
stories.summary: Mohave County will implement additional security features on paper ballots starting in 2026 and encourages other Arizona counties to do the same. The Board of Supervisors approved a contract with a Phoenix-based voting materials company that includes security measures such as embedded watermarks, visible fibers, and other anti-counterfeiting markings. While the exact utility of these features is not certain, the move aims to improve voter confidence. Research suggests wide-spread election fraud in Arizona is extremely rare.

stories.headline: Fired New College official had history of charges
stories.summary: Fred Piccolo, recently hired as New College of Florida's director of media and marketing, was fired after a background check revealed past and pending charges that had previously gone undetected. Piccolo was arrested for indecent exposure and other charges linked to incidents in Manatee County, including one involving his girlfriend's husband. The college terminated Piccolo's employment following these revelations and media inquiries.

stories.headline: Markets hit retirement savings
stories.summary: Some retired and near-retired Americans, including Michael Montgomery, have stopped opening their retirement account statements to avoid stress, amid financial market turmoil and worries about outliving their savings. The White House's simultaneous trade war and interest rate moves have increased uncertainty, leading many to adjust portfolios, but concerns remain about the broader economic impact.

stories.headline: Lunch downtown
stories.summary: A bird feeds its young inside a lamppost in downtown Safety Harbor, which was recently ranked No. 10 on USA Today's 10Best list of main streets that will "steal your heart." The ranking was determined by travel experts, editors, and public voting, highlighting the charm of Safety Harbor's thoroughfares.

stories.headline: Sentenced to life in prison as a teen, Tampa woman resentenced to 35 years in murder
stories.summary: Laisha Landrum, originally sentenced to life for a crime she committed at 16, was resentenced to 35 years for the murder of Emily Clemons. The resentencing allows for the possibility of early release after serving 85% of her term, meaning she could be released in about nine years. The decision follows several days of testimony, with consideration given to factors like her troubled upbringing and potential for rehabilitation.

stories.headline: Detroit's White Stripes headed into Rock Hall of Fame
stories.summary: The Detroit rock band White Stripes has been announced as one of the 2025 inductees into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame. Known for their influential minimalist movement and blues-rock sound, the band is the 22nd Detroit artist to be so honored. Their induction celebrates their legacy since forming in 1997 and their impact on the music scene.

stories.headline: Trump takes aim at Great Lakes
stories.summary: The Trump administration plans significant cuts to federal funding for Great Lakes science, data collection, and monitoring. The preliminary 2026 budget outline proposes eliminating federal involvement in many Great Lakes programs, cutting NOAA's budget significantly, and reducing support for environmental research and forecasting.

stories.headline: Pistons must learn from latest heartbreak
stories.summary: The Detroit Pistons faced another tough loss in the NBA playoffs, falling to the New York Knicks after a missed final shot and controversial foul call. The article reflects on the players' efforts and the emotional toll, emphasizing the need for the Pistons to learn from this experience and improve.

stories.headline: Refs blew foul call, but Detroit must rise above it
stories.summary: In a close NBA playoff game, the Detroit Pistons were defeated by the New York Knicks 94-93 after a contentious foul call in the final seconds. The author argues that Detroit must move past the controversial call and focus on overcoming challenges to advance further in the playoffs.

stories.headline: Buick ‘could just disappear’ under Trump tariffs
stories.summary: Analysts warn that the future of Buick and its new sub-brand Envision in the United States is uncertain due to tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump. The tariffs affect import costs as many Buick vehicles are shipped from South Korea and China. Concerns include potential disappearance of the Buick brand from the US market amid rising costs and trade tensions. The article highlights the potential implications of Trump's trade policies on GM's Buick brand and global supply chains.

stories.headline: Trump’s team not dissuaded by challenges of first 100 days
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has experienced more significant changes and challenges within his first 100 days in office compared to his predecessor in 2017. Despite declining approval ratings and ongoing battles with federal bureaucracy, presidential power limits, and the court system, Trump's administration continues efforts to enact sweeping changes in government policies.

stories.headline: REF-ED UP: Last-second no-call leaves Pistons on verge of elimination as they let another game slip away
stories.summary: In a closely contested basketball game, the Detroit Pistons lost to the New York Knicks 94-93 after a critical no-call in the final seconds. The Pistons were trailing by one point and had a chance to win, but the Knicks' Josh Hart disrupted their final attempt. This loss places the Pistons at a 3-1 deficit in the playoff series, with elimination looming.

stories.headline: Alpena a flash point on gender policies
stories.summary: A northern Michigan school district controversy arises as the district tests whether to follow Michigan state civil rights laws or comply with Trump administration's executive orders on gender issues. The American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan and the Alpena district's board have conflicting opinions on the appropriateness of required bathroom usage aligning with gender at birth, amid concerns of anti-harassment and discrimination policies.

stories.headline: Slowing down the House
stories.summary: A group of insurgent Texas House Republicans have declared open war on GOP leadership and the lower chamber's regular order of business, vowing to kill every local and consent calendar for the rest of the legislative session. This move will slow down legislation about a month before the session ends and raises fears among lawmakers of repeating the 2017 'Mother's Day Massacre.' The leadership team has left no other options but to burn it all down, according to state Rep. Steve Toth.

stories.headline: Semiconductor industry waits to see tariffs’ impacts
stories.summary: Tech and manufacturing companies are bracing for semiconductor tariffs following an investigation launched by President Donald Trump. The investigation focuses on national security related to importing semiconductor technology. Companies in Texas and Austin are waiting to see how to cope with the tariffs, which are part of a broader trade war involving retaliatory tariffs on chips and pharmaceuticals from other countries. The issue highlights concerns about the impact on artificial intelligence and chip manufacturing workforce training in the U.S.

stories.headline: SXSW president Forrest terminated
stories.summary: South by Southwest president Hugh Forrest, who assumed the chief office last year, has been terminated by P-MRC Holdings, LLC, a venture owned by MRC and Penske Media Corporation. The departure comes just more than a month after SXSW concluded its 2025 event. A significant leadership change is also expected for SXSW Music. Brian Hobbs will succeed Forrest as VP, with Dev Sherlock as director, effective at the end of September. Forrest was instrumental in developing SXSW’s emergence as a tech festival.

stories.headline: Diocese stymies clergy abuse investigation
stories.summary: New Jersey's top prosecutor vowed to investigate decades of sexual abuse by Catholic priests across the state, with hundreds of victims coming forward to a hotline. However, the Diocese of Camden has opposed efforts by the New Jersey attorney general to produce a report on alleged clergy abuse, stymying the investigative process and leading the case to the N.J. Supreme Court. None of those who reported abuse have testified before a grand jury despite calls to convene one, and the attorney general's office has not yet produced the report.

stories.headline: Chubby Checker approved for Rock Hall
stories.summary: Chubby Checker, the singer who popularized "The Twist," will finally get his wish to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame. At 83, the South Philly-raised artist who popularized the dance hit is being honored for his musical legacy, with a ceremony planned in November in Los Angeles. Checker expressed his joy at the induction, marking a significant milestone in his career.

stories.headline: Trump's first 100 days bring dramatic changes
stories.summary: Despite historically low approval ratings, inside the White House there is broad agreement with President Donald Trump’s policies after his first 100 days. He has enacted large changes in government and the economy, including efforts to reform the federal bureaucracy. Though his approval ratings have dropped, his administration's supporters are optimistic about the direction of the country under his leadership.

stories.headline: A deepening divisiveness
stories.summary: Elon Musk campaigned relentlessly for Trump in Pennsylvania last year and now leads the face of Democrats’ political pushback. His efforts helped Trump narrowly win Pennsylvania in 2024, pushing political divisions deeper. Musk's PAC launched the FUBAR PAC targeting Democrats with attacks on their policies and leadership. Despite Musk’s controversial presence, his influence continues to grow as he remains a major divisive figure within the political landscape.

stories.headline: Bumpy road still ahead
stories.summary: Guadalupe Street construction in Santa Fe is on track to finish soon, though the final stretch is expected to impact businesses the most. The $11 million project aims to improve safety and functionality with added sidewalks, bike lanes, new traffic signals, and landscaped medians. City officials hope the roadwork will be completed by the end of summer, but concerns remain over the effect on local enterprises.

stories.headline: 'Lean' budget has 9% spending hike
stories.summary: Santa Fe city departments see modest increases in their $479 million plan for the 2026 fiscal year. Despite the increase in property taxes, city officials justify the spending rise with growing tax revenue, while an economic downturn and federal cuts are expected to impact the city’s coffers.

stories.headline: A DIVISIVE ‘UNITY’
stories.summary: Conservative cardinals' calls for wide appeal in the pope are being perceived as attacks on Pope Francis' legacy, leading to divisions within the Church and broader implications for its future direction.

stories.headline: Timberwolves’ rally pushes L.A. to brink of elimination
stories.summary: The Timberwolves have surged in their playoff series, putting the Los Angeles team on the brink of elimination. Game details and player performances have highlighted the shift in momentum during this critical phase of the sports season.

stories.headline: At least 11 killed in SUV attack at Canadian festival
stories.summary: A violent incident occurred at the Lapa Lupa Festival in Vancouver, British Columbia, when a black Audi SUV attacked festival-goers, killing at least 11 people. The SUV crashed into crowds and then struck people selling items at a nearby booth before police intervened. The attack has shocked the community and is under investigation.

stories.headline: Ex-Las Cruces mayor running for governor — just not yet
stories.summary: Former Las Cruces Mayor Ken Miyagishima has revealed plans to run for governor but stated the official announcement will come later. Miyagishima, a Democrat, discussed his intent and the political landscape, hinting at a potential historic match-up with a Republican opponent but declined to detail his platform at this time.

stories.headline: Investigation finds system collapse in D.C. chopper, plane crash
stories.summary: An investigation has uncovered a system failure that contributed to a helicopter and plane crash in Washington D.C. The findings shed light on the causes behind the tragic accident and potential systemic issues that need to be addressed to prevent future incidents.

stories.headline: Deputy: Boilermaker Special's tire blew, leading to fatal crash
stories.summary: A deputy reported that the tire of the Boilermaker Special blew, which caused a fatal crash. Details about the incident and the investigation are provided on a following page.

stories.headline: Trump nears first 100 days, a milestone since FDR
stories.summary: President Donald Trump is approaching the 100-day mark of his second administration on April 30, a milestone historically marked by Franklin Delano Roosevelt. FDR’s first 100 days included significant reforms and programs during the Great Depression. In contrast, Trump’s administration used its first 100 days to reduce government size, cut federal agency roles, and issue executive orders targeting perceived enemies and officials.

stories.headline: Alfie the office dog wins hearts around Indiana Statehouse
stories.summary: Alfie, a friendly golden doodle, has become a beloved figure at the Indiana Statehouse, frequently joining his owner Alison Slatter during work days. Known as an office dog and previously named employee of the month, Alfie brightens the days of many staff members with his presence. His role has grown since his family brought him to work to support a relative battling cancer.

stories.headline: Bill nixes ethnic studies option
stories.summary: Indiana's State Senate narrowly passed a bill that removes the 2017 requirement for high schools to offer an optional racial or ethnic studies course. The amendment was a response to pressure from the Trump administration, which threatened to withhold education funding from states promoting diversity and inclusion programs. Critics argue the law discriminates against certain racial groups and sends a negative message regarding diversity.

stories.headline: Jakes passes leadership to next generation
stories.summary: Bishop T.D. Jakes, founder of The Potter's House megachurch, announced he is handing over leadership to his daughter Sarah Jakes Roberts and son-in-law Touré Roberts after nearly 30 years. Jakes emphasized unity and innovation while recognizing ongoing challenges like racial unrest and economic disparities. This transition comes months after a major health incident for Jakes and reflects plans for the church's future direction.

stories.headline: At conclave, new faces, fewer clues
stories.summary: The Vatican's cardinals convene to elect a new pope following Pope Francis' revolutionary papacy tenure. Uncertainty surrounds the conclave amid speculation about potential successors, as long-standing voting blocs shift and no clear front-runner has emerged. This marks a significant moment in Catholic Church history with widespread attention on the process and outcomes of this centuries-old ritual.

stories.headline: Batteries send spark to sector
stories.summary: The fast-growing lithium-ion battery industry holds promise for the Texas energy sector, potentially helping reduce emissions and support electric vehicle infrastructure despite occasional supply challenges. Texas leads in battery manufacturing with efforts focused on overcoming obstacles and integrating this clean energy technology into the state's power grid, benefiting the economy and environment over time.

stories.headline: Migrant children face new scrutiny
stories.summary: Federal agents have increased home visits in North Texas, conducting 'welfare checks' on migrant children as part of a broader scrutiny effort. Families were unsettled when agents arrived unaccompanied and requested to verify health and welfare statuses, raising concerns about treatment of undocumented migrants despite no deportation orders. Legal representatives are involved to protect affected families.

stories.headline: Trump's push to save the fading coal industry receives a warm embrace in West Virginia
stories.summary: West Virginia Coal Festival's beauty pageant winner Ava Johnson symbolizes the hopes of coal communities as President Donald Trump's efforts to revive the state's coal industry receive support. Despite the ongoing decline of coal over decades, locals hope Trump's executive orders and pledges to save coal jobs will bring renewed economic vitality. The initiative aims to offset past declines in coal due to environmental regulations and the global shift away from fossil fuels contributing to climate change.

stories.headline: Trump wants to end tech's 'woke AI' efforts
stories.summary: Technology companies could face new scrutiny over their diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts in AI products as the White House and Congress shift focus away from 'woke AI' to address harmful algorithmic discrimination. The U.S. Commerce Department is appealing for collaboration but instructing researchers to emphasize reducing ideological bias to promote human flourishing and economic competitiveness. Major tech firms like Amazon, Google, Meta, Microsoft, and OpenAI are under investigation by the House Judiciary Committee.

stories.headline: Helping hand: Tennessee statehouse passes farmland preservation fund legislation
stories.summary: The Tennessee statehouse passed legislation establishing a $25 million farmland preservation fund to financially assist farmers and forest landowners in securing permanent conservation easements, helping protect over 10 acres of farmland at risk. State Representative Greg Vital sponsored the legislation, expressing commitment to preserving farmland and open spaces in Tennessee. The fund aims to aid the Department of Agriculture in developing tools to better assist farmers in maintaining their land.

stories.headline: Republicans now hard to find for irate constituents
stories.summary: In Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania, constituents of Republican Rep. Scott Perry are finding it difficult to get public appearances or directly contact their congressman. Many constituents report no answer to calls and locked district office doors. This comes as the U.S. House is entering a recess period with members returning to their districts to focus on constituents, although some vulnerable Republicans are limiting exposure to potential backlash from President Donald Trump's early months in office.

stories.headline: Moratorium on new music venues comes up for vote
stories.summary: The Portland City Council will hold a public hearing and vote on a proposal to pause the development of large theaters and performance halls, potentially hindering a 3,300-seat concert venue in the Merrill Auditorium area. The proposal has raised concerns about local venue growth and downtown traffic. City Councilors have proposed a 180-day moratorium on new theaters and performance halls with capacities over 2,000, which could retroactively freeze pending Venue applications for Portland Music Hall.

stories.headline: Volunteers, families clean up Portland’s Eastern Promenade to mark Earth Day
stories.summary: On Earth Day, volunteers in bright raincoats cleaned Portland’s Eastern Promenade, collecting trash and debris to promote environmental stewardship. The event, organized by Karen Snyder and hosted by the Munjoy Hill Neighborhood Association, involved families and children learning about the importance of caring for the planet. Despite rescheduling due to rain, the cleanup attracted community members dedicated to keeping the area pristine, emphasizing the value of local collective action for Earth’s wellbeing.

stories.headline: Analysis: Maine’s electricity prices grew at the third fastest rate in US
stories.summary: Between 2014 and 2024, Maine's average retail electricity price increased by 55 percent, growing faster than most other states except California and Massachusetts. The price went from 12.65 cents/kWh to 19.62 cents/kWh, while the U.S. average was 10.44 to 12.99 cents/kWh. This increase challenges efforts to secure affordable and clean power as electricity demand grows. Maine faces scrutiny amid debates on why its electricity rates are rising quickly and how state energy policies can promote affordability and clean energy by 2040.

stories.headline: Trump cut a key FEMA grant. What does that mean for Maine’s projects?
stories.summary: The Biden administration faces challenges after the Trump administration ended a popular FEMA grant program called Building Resilient Infrastructure and Communities (BRIC), which had provided $133 million in local disaster resilience projects since 2020. Maine has received significant BRIC funding for resilience projects at different government levels, but future grants may be uncertain as the program's new structure continues. Local officials like Arthur Cleaves hope additional funding will be available to support coastal resilience and emergency preparedness in Maine.

stories.headline: Trump’s polls decline near 100-day mark, raising tax-plan stakes
stories.summary: Voter discontent with President Donald Trump’s economic stewardship is sinking his popularity as he approaches the symbolic 100-day mark of his second term Tuesday, ratcheting up pressure on congressional Republicans to pass his tax plan. Recent polls show a decline in support for Trump amid issues with the economy, immigration, and his tariff rollout. Republicans aim to pass the tax package without requiring Democratic votes, positioning for the 2026 midterm elections.

stories.headline: At least 11 dead in Vancouver after driver plows into street party
stories.summary: A driver plowed into a group of partygoers attending a Filipino street festival in Vancouver, British Columbia, killing at least 11 people. The city's interim police chief and officials said there may be more deaths among the dozens injured. The driver, a 30-year-old man, was in custody and had prior mental health issues. Investigators ruled out terrorism but are continuing their investigation. The incident occurred during a Lapu Lapu Day festival, honoring a national hero in the Philippines.

stories.headline: US as ‘villain’: Nationalism surges in Mexico amid Trump threats
stories.summary: Nationalism is rising in Mexico amid threats and tensions with the United States under President Trump. The phrase “Niños Héroes,” referring to young Mexican soldiers who died defending Mexico City against U.S. forces nearly 179 years ago, symbolizes Mexican resistance. Many Mexicans perceive the U.S. as a villain in the narrative, with historical and current grievances fueling nationalist sentiment. The conflict may not loom large for many Americans but remains highly significant in Mexico.

stories.headline: Pedestrian struck by car last year dies from injuries
stories.summary: Machelle Wilson, a UC Davis biostatistician who was hit by a car in October and died of complications from her injuries in March, passed away at age 64. Wilson was walking near her home when a driver struck her. She was treated at UC Davis Medical Center where brain injuries led to her decline over five months. Wilson was a mother of three and grandmother, and had been curious children in academia.
